content.text: 1 (a) List all the factors of 68.
(b) Put one pair of brackets into each calculation to make it correct.
(i) the reciprocal of \(\frac{2}{7}\),
(ii) the value of \(10^{0}\).
(c) Find
(ii) \(\sqrt{3} \times \sqrt{12}\)
(d) Calculate.
(e) Write these numbers in order of size, starting with the smallest.
(f) By writing each number in the calculation correct to 1 significant figure, work out an estimate for the value of
You must show all your working.
(i) Estimate the number of people who visit the beach in November.
(ii) The table shows the average daytime temperature, in \(^{\circ} \mathrm{C}\), in each month at the beach in the same year.
Mario says that more people visit the beach when the temperature is warmer.
Is he correct?
Explain your answer by comparing the bar chart and the table.
2 (a) The bar chart shows the number of people who visit a beach in each month in one year.
(b) The scale drawing shows the positions of two lifeguards, \(L\) and \(M\), on a beach. The scale is 1 centimetre represents 50 metres.
North M
(i) Write this number in words.
(ii) The land area of Alaska is 147 730 square kilometres.
Work out the average number of people per square kilometre.
3 (a) The population of Alaska is 735 720 .
(b) The length, \(L \mathrm{~km}\), of a race is 1569 km , correct to the nearest kilometre.
Complete this statement about the value of \(L\).
(i) Find the difference between the height of Denali and the height of Everest.
(ii) Find the difference between the maximum temperature and the minimum temperature at the top of Denali.
(iii) The maximum temperature at the top of Everest was \(27^{\circ} \mathrm{C}\) colder than the maximum temperature at the top of Denali.
Complete the table.
(c) The table gives some information about two mountains.
The temperatures are taken at the top of each mountain on the same day.

table.html:
Height in metresMaximum temperatureMinimum temperature
DenaliHighest mountain in Alaska6190\(-9^{\circ} \mathrm{C}\)\(-20^{\circ} \mathrm{C}\)
EverestHighest mountain in the world8849\(\mathrm{......}^{\circ} \mathrm{C}\)\(-38^{\circ} \mathrm{C}\)

content.text: (i) Between which two times is Tia cycling the fastest?
(ii) Andy leaves Bay Park at 1020 and runs to Sandy Cove at a constant speed of 8 km/h . He then stops to rest until 1200 .
On the travel graph, draw Andy's journey.
Ocean Park
Sandy Cove
The diagram shows the travel graph of Tia's journey.
(a) Tia cycles along the path.
The diagram shows the travel graph of Tia's journey.
(b) In June, the number of cyclists using the path is 3546 . In July, the number of cyclists using the path is 4067 .
Work out the percentage increase in the number of cyclists from June to July.
(i) Write the ratio walkers : runners in its simplest form.
(ii) In the same week, the ratio of cyclists and walkers using the path is
Find the total of the number of cyclists, walkers and runners using the path in this week.
(c) In one week, 432 walkers and 528 runners use the path.
4 A path from Bay Park to Ocean Park passes through Sandy Cove.
(i) Show that the length \(A D\) is \(5 x+8\).
(ii) The area of \(A B C D\) is \(360 \mathrm{~cm}^{2}\).
Work out the value of \(x\).
(iii) Find the total shaded area.
5 (a) In this part, all measurements are in centimetres.
The diagram shows a rectangle, \(A B C D\).
(i) Show that a maximum of 24 of these cuboids will fit inside the box.
(ii) 24 of these cuboids are placed inside the box.
Calculate the volume of empty space in the box.
Give the units of your answer.
The diagram shows an open rectangular box and a solid cuboid.
The diagram shows a solid cube with side \(x \mathrm{~cm}\).
The total surface area of the cube is \(486 \mathrm{~cm}^{2}\).
Calculate the value of \(x\).
(i) Find the value of \(p\).
Give a geometrical reason for your answer.
(ii) Find the value of \(q\).
Give a geometrical reason for your answer.
In the diagram, \(A B C\) is parallel to \(E D\).
(i) Write down the mathematical name for triangle \(O H J\).
(ii) Find the value of \(x\).
(iii) Find the value of \(y\).
\(G\) is a point on the circle, centre \(O\). \(F H J\) is a tangent to the circle at \(G\) and \(O H=H J\).
(i) Complete the scatter diagram.
The first eight points have been plotted for you.
(ii) What type of correlation is shown on the scatter diagram?
(iii) On one flight, the ticket price is much more expensive per kilometre travelled than on all of the other flights.
Draw a ring around this point on the scatter diagram.
(iv) Draw a line of best fit on the scatter diagram.
(v) Another plane travels 4500 km .
Use your line of best fit to estimate the ticket price for this flight.
7 (a) The table shows the distance, in km, a plane travels and the ticket price, in dollars, for each of 10 flights.
(b) The ticket price for a flight is \(\$ 522\). The exchange rate is 1 euro \(=\$ 1.16\).
Find the ticket price in euros.
(i) This flight takes 1 hour 24 minutes.
Work out the average speed in kilometres per hour.
(ii) For this flight, the amount of fuel used is \(3.89 \mathrm{~kg}\) per kilometre travelled. Carbon emissions are \(3.15 \mathrm{~kg}\) for each kilogram of fuel used.
Work out the carbon emissions, in kilograms, for this flight.
(c) A plane travels 939 km from London to Copenhagen.
(i) Draw the image of shape \(A\) after a reflection in the line \(y=-1\).
(ii) Describe fully the single transformation that maps shape \(A\) onto shape \(B\).
(iii) Describe fully the single transformation that maps shape \(A\) onto shape \(C\).
(iv) Complete this statement.
The area of shape \(C\) is times bigger than the area of shape \(A\).
(i) Write \(\overrightarrow{A B}\) as a column vector.
(ii) \(\overrightarrow{B C}=\left(\begin{array}{r}-4 \\ -5\end{array}\right)\)
On the grid, plot point \(C\).
(i) \(3 \mathrm{~p}\),
(c) \(\mathbf{p}=\left(\begin{array}{r}5 \\ -12\end{array}\right) \quad \mathbf{t}=\left(\begin{array}{l}4 \\ 7\end{array}\right)\)

9 (a) Alvian has a bag containing 35 counters.
6 are pink, 8 are blue and the rest are either green or yellow.
He picks one counter at random.
The probability that Alvian picks a green counter is \(\frac{2}{7}\).
Find the number of yellow counters in the bag.
(i) Complete the tree diagram.
(ii) Calculate the probability that Mateo picks two brown counters.
(b) Mateo has a box containing 15 counters, of which 7 are red and 8 are brown.
He picks one counter at random, notes the colour and replaces it in the box.
He then picks another counter at random.
(a) Draw Pattern 4.
(b) Complete the table.
(c) (i) Write down the term to term rule for continuing the sequence for the number of dots.
(ii) Find an expression, in terms of \(n\), for the number of dots in Pattern \(n\).
(d) The number of lines in Pattern \(n\) is \(4 n+1\). Meena makes the pattern which has 129 lines.
Work out the number of dots she uses to make this pattern.
10 Meena makes these patterns using dots and lines.
